caption: One of the city bridges that crosses the Siene. This is an excellent place to take pictures with the Eiffel Tower in the background. This bridge is directly across the street from the Sergei Rachmaninoff Conservatory.
Wide pedestrian only bridge giving the tourist plenty of opportunity to enjoy the view and take photographs of the sites.

Strolling across the Passerelle Debilly was a delightful surprise. This elegant footbridge offers a unique perspective of the Eiffel Tower, framing it perfectly against the Parisian skyline. The intricate ironwork and the bridge's graceful curve add to its charm. It's a hidden gem, a peaceful escape from the bustling city, offering a serene view of the Seine River.

A great location to take photos of the river and the Eiffel Tower. It’s quite close to the metro station on line 9 “Iena”, where you can walk down a set of stairs (another beautiful photo spot, by the way). And cross the road onto the bridge.  There were some people selling food and offering photos but it seemed a little sketchy. In any case, a great spot for photo taking!

Locks tied in the name of love add to the glory of this bridge. Went to see the beauty of this bridge in the past and was mesmerized upon seeing it. My brother and I tied locks here for our family and we always visit this place.  will remember to whenever we get time we will be looking to come here often thanks
Pedestrian only bridge. Walking distance from Eiffel tower.
Quite fitting to have a steel (pedestrian) bridge in the vicinity of the tower in our opinion.
The best place to put your love locks with an Eiffel Tower view  <3
Lovely bridge. Has many love locks on it. Amazing view of the tower and over the river. Close to shops and food.
Such a beautiful view on the Eifeltower. Perfect on the Day and in the night if you want so see the sparkling Eifeltower. The bridge wasn’t empty and was also very clean. Good spot!

Oh Man, the only word I could say is awesome. The bridge at night is super heart warming. I cant explain how good it felt to feel the water in dim lights. The warm lights over the bridge were dreamy. Apart from that you can find few people selling Crepes, Souvenirs, Keychains and power banks at cheap prices.  Moreover, you can find alot of photographers at the bridge, some are paid and some do for the love of photos and smiles. I was one of the photographers to spread love and do it at a cost of a smile. Over all, do visit this place. The most interesting part was the locks of love with names and dates all over the bridge. So if you are visiting with a loved one dont forget to buy the lock and place it on the bridge as a memory.  Much Love, UrooshihaYo
People start bringing their locks here, since it is not longer possible on Pont des arts. Romantic view over the Seine and on the Eiffel Tower. Good place to make a proposal... ;)
This bridge is a must see during the morning hours. The sun is rising on the Eifel Tower, the river below is placid, and the morning air is fresh. Definitely stroll through for an awesome experience.
Great bridge beside Eiffel tower . Stunning views

Now classified as one of the historical monuments in Paris, the Passerelle Debilly is a cycle and foot bridge over the River Seine that was constructed in 1900 for the World Fair and became a permanent bridge after it was relocated slightly to its current position. When plans were being put in place for the 1900 World Fair in Paris, it was decided that a temporary bridge needed to be erected in order to accommodate people wishing to go from one part of the exhibition on the left bank of the River Seine over to other exhibits on the right bank. So it was decided that a metal pedestrian bridge would be erected and demolished a few years later, just like the Eiffel Tower was supposed to have been demolished after 20 years from its inauguration at the 1889 World Fair. It was then designed by the engineers Lion, Amedee Alby and Jean Resal, who was also instrumental in the design of the impressive Alexandre III bridge in Paris, and the construction of the bridge was first approved in the October of 1898. The bridge was completed in the April of 1900 and had been referred to by different names such as the Magdeberg or the de Billy footbridge, and when the City of Paris took over the management of the structure, they had the position of it moved in 1906 to its current location.
